content: How can I help you today?

I'm struggling to feel present and engaged lately. Things at home have been really tough, and it’s affecting everything—my marriage, my relationship with my kids, my work. I honestly don’t know where to even start.

It sounds like everything feels overwhelming for you right now, with challenges in multiple areas of your life. It takes a lot of strength to share this, especially when you're feeling stuck. What feels most important for you to talk about right now?
I guess the biggest thing is my son. He’s been acting out a lot, and my wife and I can’t seem to figure out how to help him. It feels like it’s tearing everything apart, especially our marriage.

You really care about your son and want to help him, but the challenges you're facing with him are putting a strain on your marriage and creating a lot of tension. It sounds like you’re carrying a lot of responsibility right now. What do you think is behind his behavior, or what’s been hardest for you in navigating this?

I wish I knew what was behind it. He just seems angry all the time, and no matter what we say or do, it feels like we’re failing him. The hardest part is seeing my wife and me constantly arguing about what to do, and feeling like I’m not doing enough as a dad.

You want the best for your son and it’s heartbreaking to feel like your efforts aren’t helping him. It must be incredibly difficult to see the tension this is causing between you and your wife, as well as the self-doubt it’s bringing about as a father. How do you think you’ve been coping with all of this so far?
I’m not sure I’d call it coping. I’ve been shutting down a lot, withdrawing. It feels easier than facing the constant stress and arguments, but I know it’s not helping anything. I just feel so stuck.

It sounds like withdrawing has felt like the only way to avoid the heaviness of stress and conflict, but at the same time, you’re aware it might not be bringing the relief or solutions you truly need. Feeling stuck can be so frustrating. What might help you feel unstuck, even in small ways?

I honestly don’t know. I guess just having some kind of plan or feeling like I’m making progress would help. Right now, it feels like I’m failing on all fronts—at home, with my son, with my wife, even at work. I don’t know where to start to fix it.

The weight of feeling like you’re struggling in so many areas of life is really heavy, and it sounds like having a sense of direction or progress could make a difference for you. You mentioned earlier that your son is a big focus for you—what kind of change or progress would feel meaningful when it comes to supporting him?

I'm not sure. I just want him to be happy again, you know? To not feel so angry or upset all the time. I want to feel like I actually know how to help him. Right now, I don’t even know what he needs from me.

You deeply want your son to feel happier and less overwhelmed, and it’s clear how much you care about understanding and supporting him. Feeling unsure of what he needs must add to the frustration for you. What do you think might help open up space to better understand what he’s feeling or what he needs?

Maybe just finding a way to actually talk to him, without it turning into an argument or meltdown. I don’t even know if he’d open up to me, but I feel like we’re just kind of talking past each other lately. I want to connect with him, but I don’t know how.

It means so much to you to truly connect with your son, especially when communication has been such a struggle. You’re open to trying, even though it feels uncertain, and that takes a lot of courage. What’s one small step you might consider to create space for a calmer, more open conversation with him?

Maybe I could try setting some time aside just for him, like doing something he enjoys without bringing up any heavy conversations at first. I feel like if I can rebuild some kind of bond, maybe it’ll be easier to talk to him later. I don’t know if that’s the right approach, though.

Taking time to focus on something he enjoys sounds like a thoughtful way to rebuild trust and connection—it’s clear how much you want to start small and meet him where he’s at. It sounds like you’re aiming to strengthen the bond first before diving into deeper conversations, which could be a meaningful step. Would you like to explore more ideas together or sit with this for now?

Taking time to focus on something he enjoys sounds like a great way to rebuild connection—it shows him that you care and creates a safe space without pressure. It’s hard to say what’s “right” because every child is different, but this approach seems like a positive way forward. What sorts of things does he enjoy that you could try together?

It seems like a good idea. I know he loves video games and soccer, but he’s not really doing much of either these days. Maybe if I ask him to play a game with me or kick the soccer ball around, it’ll remind him he has those outlets. I think I’ll try that.

That sounds like a great idea. Even small moments like playing a game or kicking a ball together can communicate that you’re there for him and want to spend time with him. It might take time, but it’s a step in the right direction. How do you feel about trying this?
It feels like something I can do. It’s not overwhelming, and it might be a good way to just spend time with him without pressure. I’m still nervous about it, but it seems worth a try.
